title: Late 19th century medal clasp punched font
author: Matthew Holland

comments.content:
I have been asked to make a copy of this clasp. Before I draw up all the text, I wondered if there was a regular font close to it. It's a little like a clarendon but with squarish serifs and a different leg on the R.  
anybody know?  
Thanks very much,  
Matt.

Clarenden Bold looks good - maybe the R from CAM by You Work For Them

[http://www.youworkforthem.com/font/T0005/ywft-cam](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317161142/http:/www.youworkforthem.com/font/T0005/ywft-cam "http://www.youworkforthem.com/font/T0005/ywft-cam")

You may also consider **[Rosewood](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317161142/http:/www.findmyfont.com/index.php/fonts/font-preview?fset=Adobe&ffam=Rosewood%20Std%20-%20Fill&fid=a40001771306033d6e47af7c997459f9&fsize=60&text=KANDAHAR%20AHMED%20KHEL&wrap=2)** or a manually compressed **[Lino Letter (Bold)](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317161142/http:/www.findmyfont.com/index.php/fonts/font-preview?fset=Linotype&ffam=LinoLetter%20Small%20Caps%20%26%20Oldstyl%20-%20Bold&fid=b11ff9b67e1dfa758c98303b93e162ac&fsize=60&text=KANDAHAR%20AHMED%20KHEL&wrap=2)** (a bit more square serifs?) but Clarendon is probably closer to the general style of your sample.

Thank you for your help!  
Best regards  
Matthew.

Not a lot of detail so lots of room for error.  
But I believe I see a the remnants of square serifs rather than the cove used in Clarendon. This means that the designer would have based the design on a font style then called Antique -- which we now call Egyptian. To recreate I could perhaps go with a modified Lino Letter Bold compressed to 80% with an adjustment to make the leg on R more vertical. Hope this is of some help.  
Don
